civilCases.name: Moyo v. Ndlovu Construction Company
civilCases.facts: Sibongile Moyo filed a lawsuit against Ndlovu Construction Company, alleging breach of contract and poor workmanship. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant failed to complete the construction project as agreed and delivered substandard results.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Ndlovu Construction Company liable for breach of contract and poor workmanship. The defendant was ordered to compensate Sibongile Moyo for the financial losses incurred, provide remedial work, and pay damages for the inconvenience caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 56(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, prompt, efficient, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Chikwava v. Chisango Health Clinic
civilCases.facts: Tatenda Chikwava filed a lawsuit against Chisango Health Clinic, alleging medical negligence. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's negligent actions during treatment resulted in further health complications.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Chisango Health Clinic guilty of medical negligence. The defendant was ordered to compensate Tatenda Chikwava for medical expenses, pain, suffering, and any other damages incurred.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 76(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to have access to basic healthcare services, including reproductive healthcare.

civilCases.name: Mukwamba v. Maposa Law Firm
civilCases.facts: Tendai Mukwamba filed a lawsuit against Maposa Law Firm, alleging professional negligence and failure to provide adequate legal representation. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's negligence and inadequate legal advice resulted in an unfavorable outcome in a legal matter.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Maposa Law Firm liable for professional negligence. The defendant was ordered to compensate Tendai Mukwamba for any financial losses incurred due to the inadequate legal representation and provide damages for the negative impact caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 70(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to access to justice, including the right to competent legal representation.

civilCases.name: Ncube v. Masuku Insurance Company
civilCases.facts: Bongani Ncube filed a lawsuit against Masuku Insurance Company, alleging unfair denial of an insurance claim. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant unreasonably refused to honor a valid claim, causing financial hardship and distress.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Masuku Insurance Company guilty of unfair denial of an insurance claim. The defendant was ordered to compensate Bongani Ncube for the financial losses incurred, provide coverage as per the policy, and pay damages for the emotional distress caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 69(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Dube v. Makoni Educational Institution
civilCases.facts: Sipho Dube filed a lawsuit against Makoni Educational Institution, alleging discrimination based on disability. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant denied reasonable accommodations and equal educational opportunities due to their disability.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Makoni Educational Institution guilty of discrimination based on disability. The defendant was ordered to provide reasonable accommodations, ensure equal educational opportunities, and pay damages for the discrimination suffered by Sipho Dube.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 56(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, prompt, efficient, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Mazibuko v. Chikore Real Estate Agency
civilCases.facts: Nomsa Mazibuko filed a lawsuit against Chikore Real Estate Agency, alleging fraudulent misrepresentation. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant provided false information about a property, leading to financial losses and misinformed investment decisions.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Chikore Real Estate Agency liable for fraudulent misrepresentation. The defendant was ordered to compensate Nomsa Mazibuko for the financial losses incurred, provide restitution for the misrepresented property, and pay damages for the misleading information provided.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 68(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Moyo v. Chirambira Construction Company
civilCases.facts: Tawanda Moyo filed a lawsuit against Chirambira Construction Company, alleging breach of contract and failure to complete a construction project within the agreed timeframe. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's delays caused financial losses and inconvenience.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Chirambira Construction Company liable for breach of contract and failure to meet agreed deadlines. The defendant was ordered to compensate Tawanda Moyo for the financial losses incurred, provide completion of the project as per the contract, and pay damages for the inconvenience caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 56(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, prompt, efficient, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Chisenga v. Kamunda Health Clinic
civilCases.facts: Patience Chisenga filed a lawsuit against Kamunda Health Clinic, alleging medical negligence resulting in severe health complications. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's negligent actions during treatment caused permanent harm and emotional distress.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Kamunda Health Clinic guilty of medical negligence. The defendant was ordered to compensate Patience Chisenga for medical expenses, ongoing medical care, loss of income, and damages for the pain, suffering, and emotional distress endured.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 76(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to have access to basic healthcare services, including reproductive healthcare.

civilCases.name: Khumalo v. Nyathi Law Firm
civilCases.facts: Mthokozisi Khumalo filed a lawsuit against Nyathi Law Firm, alleging professional negligence and failure to provide competent legal advice. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant's negligence and inadequate representation led to an unfavorable legal outcome and financial losses.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Nyathi Law Firm liable for professional negligence. The defendant was ordered to compensate Mthokozisi Khumalo for the financial losses incurred due to the inadequate legal representation, provide restitution if possible, and pay damages for the negative impact caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 70(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to access to justice, including the right to competent legal representation.

civilCases.name: Mashingaidze v. Moyo Insurance Company
civilCases.facts: Rumbidzai Mashingaidze filed a lawsuit against Moyo Insurance Company, alleging unfair denial of an insurance claim. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant unreasonably refused to honor a valid claim, causing financial hardship and distress.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Moyo Insurance Company guilty of unfair denial of an insurance claim. The defendant was ordered to compensate Rumbidzai Mashingaidze for the financial losses incurred, provide coverage as per the policy, and pay damages for the emotional distress caused.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 69(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.

civilCases.name: Gwaze v. Muchena Educational Institution
civilCases.facts: Grace Gwaze filed a lawsuit against Muchena Educational Institution, alleging discrimination based on religion. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant denied her admission and equal educational opportunities based on her religious beliefs.
civilCases.outcome: The court found Muchena Educational Institution guilty of religious discrimination. The defendant was ordered to admit Grace Gwaze, provide equal educational opportunities, and pay damages for the discrimination suffered.
civilCases.constitutionalCitation: Section 56(1) of the Zimbabwean Constitution: Every person has the right to administrative conduct that is lawful, prompt, efficient, reasonable, proportionate, and procedurally fair.
